verses.text: Then the Israelites set out and camped in the plains of Moab, beyond the Jordan at Jericho.
verses.comment: Faithful to the Hebrew text. 'Plains of Moab' and 'beyond the Jordan at Jericho' rendered for clarity.

verses.text: Balak the son of Zippor saw all that Israel had done to the Amorites.
verses.comment: The name Balak and his genealogy translated plainly.

verses.text: Moab was greatly afraid of the people, because they were many; and Moab was overcome with dread because of the Israelites.
verses.comment: 'Overcome with dread' reflects the Hebrew 'sick with fear.'

verses.text: Moab said to the elders of Midian, 'Now this company will lick up all that is around us, as the ox licks up the grass of the field.' Balak the son of Zippor was king of Moab at that time.
verses.comment: 'Lick up' maintains vivid Hebrew imagery.

verses.text: So he sent messengers to Balaam the son of Beor at Pethor, which is near the River, in the land of the people of his country, to call him, saying, 'Behold, a people has come out of Egypt. They cover the surface of the land, and they are dwelling opposite me.'
verses.comment: ‘The River’ refers to the Euphrates. 'People of his country' matches uncertain Hebrew phrase.

verses.text: 'Come now, curse this people for me, for they are too mighty for me. Perhaps I may be able to defeat them and drive them out of the land, for I know that whomever you bless is blessed, and whomever you curse is cursed.'
verses.comment: Echoes blessing/curse formula found in Genesis 12:3.

verses.text: So the elders of Moab and the elders of Midian departed with the fees for divination in their hand, and they came to Balaam and gave him Balak’s message.
verses.comment: 'Fees for divination' is literal rendering; implies payment for spiritual services.

verses.text: And he said to them, 'Stay here tonight, and I will bring back to you whatever the LORD speaks to me.' So the princes of Moab stayed with Balaam.
verses.comment: 'Princes' as leaders of Moab; 'the LORD' is Yahweh.

verses.text: God came to Balaam and said, 'Who are these men with you?'
verses.comment: 'God came to Balaam' is literal; maintains divine-human interaction.

verses.text: And Balaam said to God, 'Balak the son of Zippor, king of Moab, has sent word to me.'
verses.comment: Simple restatement of the previous message.

verses.text: 'Behold, the people have come out of Egypt, and they cover the surface of the land. Now, come, curse them for me. Perhaps I will be able to fight against them and drive them out.'
verses.comment: Direct quote from earlier, preserving repetition for emphasis.

verses.text: But God said to Balaam, 'You shall not go with them. You shall not curse the people, for they are blessed.'
verses.comment: 'They are blessed' stated plainly as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: So Balaam rose up in the morning and said to the princes of Balak, 'Go to your own land, for the LORD has refused to let me go with you.'
verses.comment: Reflected Hebrew verbs literally.

verses.text: So the princes of Moab rose and went to Balak and said, 'Balaam refuses to come with us.'
verses.comment: 'Refuses' is a clear rendering of the meaning.

verses.text: Once again, Balak sent princes, more numerous and more honorable than they.
verses.comment: 'More honorable' translates the Hebrew ‘kavod.'

verses.text: And they came to Balaam and said to him, 'Thus says Balak the son of Zippor, “Let nothing hinder you from coming to me,”'
verses.comment: 'Let nothing hinder you' is a literal translation.

verses.text: 'for I will certainly honor you greatly, and whatever you say to me I will do. So come, curse this people for me.'
verses.comment: 'Honor you greatly' and 'whatever you say' translate directly from Hebrew.

verses.text: But Balaam answered and said to the servants of Balak, 'If Balak would give me his house full of silver and gold, I could not go beyond the command of the LORD my God to do either less or more.'
verses.comment: Phrase ‘either less or more’ is idiomatic for absolutely nothing.

verses.text: 'Now, therefore, please stay here tonight as well, that I may know what more the LORD may say to me.'
verses.comment: Balaam seeks further instructions from Yahweh.

verses.text: And God came to Balaam at night and said to him, 'If the men have come to call you, rise, go with them; but only do what I tell you.'
verses.comment: 'Only do what I tell you' is literal.

verses.text: So Balaam rose up in the morning, saddled his donkey, and went with the princes of Moab.
verses.comment: Maintains word order and inclusion of donkey for narrative continuity.

verses.text: But God’s anger was kindled because he went, and the angel of the LORD stood in the road as his adversary. Now he was riding on his donkey, and his two servants were with him.
verses.comment: 'As his adversary' is literal for 'to oppose him.'

verses.text: And the donkey saw the angel of the LORD standing in the road with a drawn sword in his hand, and the donkey turned aside out of the road and went into the field. So Balaam struck the donkey to turn her back onto the road.
verses.comment: 'Drawn sword' is important for the threat of judgment.

verses.text: Then the angel of the LORD stood in a narrow path between the vineyards, with a wall on this side and a wall on that side.
verses.comment: Phrase 'narrow path' and 'with a wall ... on that side' preserves Hebrew parallelism.

verses.text: And when the donkey saw the angel of the LORD, she pressed herself against the wall and crushed Balaam’s foot against the wall. So he struck her again.
verses.comment: 'Crushed his foot' is a literal translation.

verses.text: Then the angel of the LORD went further and stood in a narrow place where there was no way to turn either to the right or to the left.
verses.comment: 'No way to turn' translates Hebrew phrase for 'no room to turn.'

verses.text: When the donkey saw the angel of the LORD, she lay down under Balaam, and Balaam’s anger was kindled, and he struck the donkey with his staff.
verses.comment: 'Kindled' is common biblical motif for anger.

verses.text: Then the LORD opened the mouth of the donkey, and she said to Balaam, 'What have I done to you that you have struck me these three times?'
verses.comment: Miraculous speech emphasized as in the text.

verses.text: And Balaam said to the donkey, 'Because you have made a fool of me! If I had a sword in my hand, I would kill you right now.'
verses.comment: 'Made a fool of me' is literal Hebrew; preserves intensity of insult.

verses.text: The donkey said to Balaam, 'Am I not your donkey, upon which you have ridden all your life up to this day? Have I ever been accustomed to do so to you?' He said, 'No.'
verses.comment: 'All your life' is literal.

verses.text: Then the LORD opened Balaam’s eyes, and he saw the angel of the LORD standing in the road, with his drawn sword in his hand. He bowed down and fell on his face.
verses.comment: 'Bowed down and fell on his face' is a common Hebrew posture of humility.

verses.text: And the angel of the LORD said to him, 'Why have you struck your donkey these three times? Behold, I have come out to oppose you because your way is reckless before me.'
verses.comment: 'Reckless before me' is literal for 'your way is perverse.'

verses.text: The donkey saw me and turned aside from me these three times. If she had not turned aside from me, I would surely have killed you by now and let her live.'
verses.comment: 'Let her live' is literal.

verses.text: Then Balaam said to the angel of the LORD, 'I have sinned, for I did not know that you stood in the road against me. Now, therefore, if it is evil in your eyes, I will turn back.'
verses.comment: 'In your eyes' is a literal Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: The angel of the LORD said to Balaam, 'Go with the men, but you shall only speak the word that I tell you.' So Balaam went with the princes of Balak.
verses.comment: 'Only speak the word' underscores prophetic restriction.

verses.text: When Balak heard that Balaam had come, he went out to meet him at the city of Moab, which is on the border of the Arnon, at the utmost end of the border.
verses.comment: 'Utmost end' is literal.

verses.text: And Balak said to Balaam, 'Did I not send to you to call you? Why did you not come to me? Am I truly not able to honor you?'
verses.comment: 'Am I truly not able to honor you?' is literal Hebrew.

verses.text: Balaam said to Balak, 'Behold, I have come to you! Do I now have any power at all to say anything? The word that God puts in my mouth, that I must speak.'
verses.comment: 'Puts in my mouth' is a Hebrew prophetic phrase.

verses.text: Then Balaam went with Balak, and they came to Kiriath-huzoth.
verses.comment: 'Kiriath-huzoth' name left as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: And Balak sacrificed oxen and sheep, and sent some to Balaam and to the princes who were with him.
verses.comment: 'Sacrificed oxen and sheep' is literal.

verses.text: And in the morning Balak took Balaam and brought him up to the high places of Baal. And from there he saw a portion of the people.
verses.comment: 'High places of Baal' refers to site of pagan worship; 'a portion' or 'some of the people.'
